text: “Who will hire me / Now that my spells are so easily broken, my warnings useless”: A poem by Patricia Spears Jones. https://t.co/kdM7si6mrA

text: “The more time I spent with my father-in-law’s books, the more profoundly they seemed to be not revealing him but hiding him, like some word-wreathed, untranslatable mausoleum.” https://t.co/3jG7220kyg

name: NewYorker
text: The fast-food workers featured in Richard Renaldi’s photographs are “people that millions of Americans see every day—but, at the same time, they’re invisible, because a lot of low-wage labor isn’t appreciated and is taken for granted,” he said. https://t.co/vUIkdD755g

name: NewYorker
text: Has a desire to protect children put their long-term well-being at stake? “My biggest concern is that we’re going to lose these kids,” one teacher says. “They might never come back.” https://t.co/dO2MexKEJa

text: Mitski on her obsessive fans, growing up as “an independent-study kind of girl,” and her fascination with murder podcasts. https://t.co/bTuqLrzkau

name: NewYorker
text: For music, time is space, and Sonny Rollins is a virtual landscape artist, one who sees panoramically and travels extensively through the musical realm of his time. https://t.co/dj1Mo42qwQ

name: NewYorker
text: With an end to the coronavirus pandemic in sight, our job is to get everyone around us safely there: it was devastatingly sad that people died of COVID-19 last March, but such deaths would be tragic in a different way this March, @BillMcKibben writes. https://t.co/PZoLYzkZej

text: Inertia and vested interest are the main reasons our energy systems have been slow to change, even though rapid climate change represents the ultimate in imaginable violence, injustice, and chaos. https://t.co/0Unv62FF8f

name: NewYorker
text: Banks have helped cause much of the climate crisis we find ourselves in; it would be fascinating if they turned out to be one of the solutions. https://t.co/Xic2wFsJ7D

text: In August, the Big Ten Conference announced that it was postponing its season until the spring. College football players had begun returning to practice in June, and team after team around the country had suffered outbreaks of SARS-CoV-2. https://t.co/eBHyXMSo1j

text: “The space inside a television is familiar yet alien, like one of those dreams of being in your house but the house isn’t your house,” David Gilbert writes, in a new Personal History. “It is uncanny.” https://t.co/zDIMDlxWTi

text: .@JaneMayerNYer reports on the grave legal and ﬁnancial threats looming over Donald Trump, and how they might play out if he loses the election. https://t.co/xWAUmkpXL5

text: .@PaulSalopek reports from northeastern India, where one man is working to revive a network of “Buddha trails” for pilgrims and tourists, in the cradle of the world’s fourth-largest religion. https://t.co/UGOB2INzy8

name: NewYorker
text: Under any circumstances, putting medicine into glass vials is a tricky business. Getting COVID-19 vaccines out will require more than a billion vials to be manufactured, ﬁlled, and shipped, at top speed and in some cases under extreme stress. https://t.co/xtjXeb9MhN

name: NewYorker
text: In gentrifying neighborhoods, empty houses are sitting ducks. For cheap security, real-estate companies hire the homeless to guard expensive properties. The rules are simple: don’t host guests, don’t talk to anyone, and don’t leave. https://t.co/ju1YEbLCkC

name: NewYorker
text:
We can no longer meet our moral and practical burdens simply by reducing our own carbon emissions, @BillMcKibben writes, in his latest Climate Crisis newsletter. We also need to make amends.
https://t.co/hidK82A6dw

name: NewYorker
text:
An illuminating new documentary follows four retired filmmakers in Sudan, where all of the movie theatres have long been closed for political reasons, as they try to reopen an abandoned, open-air, amphitheatre-like movie house.
https://t.co/QLQ4HDZiLS
